title: Polar Function - Describing Behaviors - Part B

content.description: Let <math> <semantics> <mrow> <mi>r</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo> <mi>θ</mi> <mo>)</mo></mrow> </mrow> <annotation encoding="MathType-MTEF">MathType@MTEF@5@5@@3C70@</annotation> </semantics> </math> be a polar function in the polar coordinate system, where <math> <semantics> <mrow> <mi>f</mi><mtext> </mtext><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>θ</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>=</mo><mo>−</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>5</mn><mi>cos</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mn>3</mn><msup> <mi>θ</mi> <mn>2</mn> </msup> <mo>−</mo><mn>2</mn><mo stretchy="false">)</mo> </mrow> <annotation encoding="MathType-MTEF">MathType@MTEF@5@5@@495C@</annotation> </semantics> </math>. Let <math> <semantics> <mrow> <mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>g</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo> </mrow> <annotation encoding="MathType-MTEF">MathType@MTEF@5@5@+=feaaguart1ev2aqatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbdfgBPjMCPbqedmvETj2BSbqefm0B1jxALjhiov2DaebbnrfifHhDYfgasaacH8Xr=y0tbbg9q8qqaqpepec8Eeeq0tXdbba9frFj0=OqFL0dbba9LqpC0db9Fve9pce9v8qqaq=dir=xirpG0tb9fr=xfr=xfrpeWZqaaeaabiGaciaacaqabeaadaqaaqaaaOqaaiaadMhacqGH9aqpcaWGNbGaaiikaiaadIhacaGGPaaaaa@3B8D@</annotation> </semantics> </math> be a function in the rectangular coordinate system, where <math> <semantics> <mrow> <mi>g</mi><mtext> </mtext><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>=</mo><mo>−</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>5</mn><mi>cos</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mn>3</mn><msup> <mi>x</mi> <mn>2</mn> </msup> <mo>−</mo><mn>2</mn><mo stretchy="false">)</mo> </mrow> <annotation encoding="MathType-MTEF">MathType@MTEF@5@5@@47EB@</annotation> </semantics> </math>. The domain of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mn>f</mn> </math> is <math> <semantics> <mrow> <mn>0</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>θ</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>1.5</mn> </mrow> <annotation encoding="MathType-MTEF">MathType@MTEF@5@5@@3E4F@</annotation> </semantics> </math>, and the domain of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mn>g</mn> </math> is <math> <semantics> <mrow> <mn>0</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>1.5</mn> </mrow> <annotation encoding="MathType-MTEF">MathType@MTEF@5@5@@3D96@</annotation> </semantics> </math>.
content.question:
Part B

In the polar coordinate system, determine the point on the graph of <math> <semantics> <mrow> <mi>r</mi> <mo>=</mo> <mi>f</mi> <mo stretchy="false">(</mo> <mi>θ</mi> <mo stretchy="false">)</mo> </mrow> <annotation encoding="MathType-MTEF">MathType@MTEF@5@5@+=feaaguart1ev2aqatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbdfgBPjMCPbqedmvETj2BSbqefm0B1jxALjhiov2DaebbnrfifHhDYfgasaacH8Xr=y0tbbg9q8qqaqpepec8Eeeq0tXdbba9frFj0=OqFL0dbba9LqpC0db9Fve9pce9v8qqaq=dir=xirpG0tb9fr=xfr=xfrpeWZqaaeaabiGaciaacaqabeaadaqaaqaaaOqaaiaadkhacqGH9aqpcaWGMbGaaiikaiabeI7aXjaacMcaaaa@3C3E@</annotation> </semantics> </math> that is farthest from the origin for <math> <semantics> <mrow> <mn>0</mn> <mo>≤</mo> <mi>θ</mi> <mo>≤</mo> <mn>1.5</mn> </mrow> <annotation encoding="MathType-MTEF">MathType@MTEF@5@5@@3E4F@</annotation> </semantics> </math>. Give a reason for your answer.

frqParts.text:
Part B

In the polar coordinate system, determine the point on the graph of <math> <semantics> <mrow> <mi>r</mi> <mo>=</mo> <mi>f</mi> <mo stretchy="false">(</mo> <mi>θ</mi> <mo stretchy="false">)</mo> </mrow> <annotation encoding="MathType-MTEF">MathType@MTEF@5@5@+=feaaguart1ev2aqatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbdfgBPjMCPbqedmvETj2BSbqefm0B1jxALjhiov2DaebbnrfifHhDYfgasaacH8Xr=y0tbbg9q8qqaqpepec8Eeeq0tXdbba9frFj0=OqFL0dbba9LqpC0db9Fve9pce9v8qqaq=dir=xirpG0tb9fr=xfr=xfrpeWZqaaeaabiGaciaacaqabeaadaqaaqaaaOqaaiaadkhacqGH9aqpcaWGMbGaaiikaiabeI7aXjaacMcaaaa@3C3E@</annotation> </semantics> </math> that is farthest from the origin for <math> <semantics> <mrow> <mn>0</mn> <mo>≤</mo> <mi>θ</mi> <mo>≤</mo> <mn>1.5</mn> </mrow> <annotation encoding="MathType-MTEF">MathType@MTEF@5@5@@3E4F@</annotation> </semantics> </math>. Give a reason for your answer.

skill.text: Skill 3.A: Describe the characteristics of a function with varying levels of precision, depending on the function representation and available mathematical tools.
